content.description: Face to cracks.  Moves right in to the larger crack for a bit then back left.
content.protection: Bolt and a super light rack up to a blue camalot.
content.location: Start is the same as Fire Breathing Craggin.

content.description: Uninspiring to look at but turns out to have some good climbing on it.  Stays right of the weedy gully until it is easy to move left without any gardening.  Rock gets better and better on the second half.  You will be surprised at the amount of climbing even where it looks like it will be a cruise.
content.location: Starts just right of a very vegetated weakness on the right side of the main wall.

content.description: Multiple roof moves and a thin face finish.  Clipping the last bolt is a little spooky feeling even though the bolt is just under your feet.  A little working around to get into the right position will make the clip pretty straight forward.
content.location: Center of the shorter face left of the main wall.

content.description: A short bit of chimney leads to good face sustained face climbing. Move left out of the chimney at the 3rd bolt.
content.location: On the shorter wall left of the main face.  Starts in a chimney on the right then steps on to face.

content.protection: Bolts a purple, green, yellow and red camalot will get you to the top quite safely.
content.location: Arete in the gully that is 100ft. or so to the left of the main wall.

content.description: Short and in your face until the end.  Good moves on great rock.  Climbing this low at this time of year might lead others to question the size of ones brain or if you even have one.
content.location: In a gully about 100 feet left of the main wall.  You can see this short steep red face as you get close to the main wall.

content.description: Fun little face climb with some good edging in the middle.
content.location: On the left end of the A Hour Crag.  Climb up the gully to a whitish rock with an arete that has a crack on the arete.

content.description: The crux starts a few feet up and ends when you move left to clip the anchors.  Sustained climbing on good rock with a few thin finger locks along the way.
content.location: Face right of the arete in the gully on the far left end of A Hour Crag.

content.description: This is one of the last routes Jim Scott helped establish. I remember him telling me that he and Doug had top-roped a line and that we should go bolt it. I wasn't too inspired when Jim told me about it but Doug ever since Jim died has felt like it was unfinished business. Today we went out and worked out the crux which is about 10 feet up and hard to read. Unfortunately this hard steep section leads to fun but much easier climbing so it is no classic but worth doing if you are there. You can easily TR the crux from the anchors on the route to the right but please use your own draws so you don't ruin the fixed lower offs.
content.location: Left of the bolted chimney with a low start bolt.

content.description: Slightly overhanging orange face with moves to a huge jug.  A move or so up the arete then back left and over the roof. A lot of movement on a very short route.
content.location: Right side of the orange face up in a gully about 100 feet left of the main wall.

content.description: This climb stays left of the crack that leads to the large chimney that splits the crag until you get into the chimney for about 15 feet.  The step back left out of the chimney has a bit of chossy rock but is pretty cool as is most of the climbing on this moderate route.
content.location: Just left of chimney that splits the main wall.  The first three bolts are not camo painted.

content.description:
This is the main feature you can see from the parking area. It's a bit dirty in parts but fun to do if you're out there... and you like chimneys... and loose rock... and dirt. 

  Avoid the dangerous stuff in the last 20' by stepping out left to the belay/rap bolts on top of "1,2,3 Stop."
content.location: Right of "1,2,3 Stop" and left of "Amateur Hour."

content.description: This climb is very sustained and the climbing keeps you interested to the anchors.
content.location: Goes up the face just right of the chimney route.

content.description:
Climb past a bolt along right-diagonalling dirty steps to a small overhang. (The new Direct Start is better.) The original route steps right under the overhang then up along a thin crack to right side of small ledge with a bolt. Up and right to another bolt, then straight up into a crack that leads to the top. 

5.9R var. : At the small overhang, move up and left to nice crack leading to left side of the small ledge. Continue up runout face to engage left leaning crack then wander to top. (SG, JJ, 1982) 

"Running Man" direct start (5.8) Start on right side of face in a wide crack by tree. Diagonal left past bolt to tiny gear placements, then straight up steep face past another bolt to intersect A.H. just after "small overhang."  (Derek Anderson, Aaron Marks 2012)
content.protection:
Small to medium cams and stoppers.   We pulled (easily) the 5 original 1/4" bolts and replaced 3, digging out extra gear placements. It's still a bit spicy for a 5.7 lead. 

  Take some larger gear if doing the variation.
content.location:
This right-diagonalling route starts to the right of the "crack to chimney" line seen from the parking lot. 

Descent: Either hike off right or scramble to tree at top of "crack to chimney" route and rig a quick belay down 15 feet to the 2-bolt anchor for "1,2,3 Stop", to climber's left of the chimney. 30M rap.

content.description: Climb past 5 bolts to right side of hole in the rock. Up past 1 more bolt to engage crack that widens and angles right to 2-bolt belay/rap anchor.
content.location:
Starts just left of "crack to chimney" line seen from parking lot. 

  30M rap to the ground with rope to spare.

content.description:
NW facing white rock with grey bands seen from the Molino Overlook parking circle. It is a short distance SW along the ridge from where the trail to the Ruins meets the ridgeline. 

  If anybody knows the "established name" for the rock or has a better idea, let me know.
